reflection: Swapping (4, 5) 3 with (5, 5) 1 converted both spots to 4s and shuffled colours around the centre columns. No immediate 3-in-a-row was formed, so the move scored nothing, but it did lower the number of 3s on the board and raised 4s, slightly diversifying colours. Potential moves rose from 30 to 32, so the grid is now a bit richer in options. Several near-matches cluster around rows 1-2 and columns 3-5; focus on completing those (e.g., shift col-3 pieces upward) to trigger cascades. Prioritize moves that clear the dense 3s to open the board further.

The swap of (3,4) and (3,5) merely turned a 4-3 pair into a 3-4 pair—no match resulted, and potential moves dropped from 32 to 27. Counts shifted only slightly, so the move gained no points and didn’t open meaningful cascades. Plenty of two-in-a-row setups remain; the richest are in color-4 clusters. For a quick score, swap (2,5) 3 with (2,4) 4 to create three 4s vertically in column 5, or target other spots where a single move will turn a pair into a triple rather than making more pairs.

Swapping (0,1) with (1,1) only shuffled a few candies in the upper-left but produced no 3-in-a-row; color totals barely moved and the list of 27 potential moves is unchanged. In short, the move cost a turn without scoring or creating fresh openings. Look for swaps that complete existing pairs: e.g., column 2 already has two 4’s at rows 2-3—bringing a third 4 down (swap (4,2)↔(4,3) or (3,1)↔(3,2)) would score immediately. Also inspect the 3/4 clusters around (5,4-6) and (6,3-5). Prioritize moves that guarantee matches rather than lateral color shifts.

The row-5 swap (4 ↔ 2) shifted colours but cleared nothing, so it cost a turn without scoring. Still, it nudged the board into a looser layout: potential moves rose from 27 to 31, leaving many fresh options.  Strongest opportunity: column 2 already has two 4’s stacked (rows 2-3); swapping row 1, col 1 (4) with row 1, col 2 (1) would drop a third 4 on top for a clean vertical crush.  Prioritise moves that finish existing pairs—especially columns 2 and 5—to guarantee matches and open cascades.

The swap at (3,3)↔(4,3) only exchanged a 3 and a 2; no three-in-a-row formed, no candies cleared, and the pool of potential moves actually shrank (31 → 25). The board is now even more 4-heavy (21 fours), but matches remain fragmentary—mostly isolated pairs such as 4-3-4 in row 6 or 1-2 pairs in row 7. Look for moves that turn those pairs into triples: e.g., slide the 4 at (2,5) down or the 4 at (6,5) left to complete 4-4-4, or shift a 1 into column 4 to chain three 1’s vertically.

Swapping (3,1) with (3,2) triggered cascades: 4s and 2s disappeared, raising 1s/3s and cutting total 4s from 21→17, 2s from 15→12. The board reshuffled noticeably (row 3 now 1-3-1-1-2-4…), so the move was productive. Potential matches fell from 25 to 21, yet plenty remain—many clustered around rows 3-5 (e.g., 3-4-5 columns) and the central 4-2 pairs. Look for swaps that extend the frequent 1/3 chains or exploit the dense 4s in columns 4-5; vertical plays there could trigger further cascades.

The swap (2,1) ⇄ (3,1) only traded a 1 and a 3; no three-in-a-row resulted, and potential matches dropped from 21 to 18. Thus the move neither scored nor clearly improved the board. Several easy setups remain: horizontal 3-pairs at (1,0-1), (2,3-4), (5,0-1) and vertical 2-pairs in columns 0, 4, 5. Prioritise swaps that extend these pairs into triples—especially around columns 4-5, where stacked 2/4 and 4/2 pairs could cascade. Avoid lateral shuffles that don’t touch existing pairs; aim for vertical clears to create space and new candy flow.

Swapping (3,4) with (3,5) dropped a 2 into column 5, completing a vertical run of four 2’s (rows 2-5). Those candies vanished and the refill shifted counts (2’s −4, 3’s +2, 1’s +1). Good move: it scored immediately and scrambled the centre columns, raising available potentials from 18 to 24.

The board is now rich in “two-in-a-row” setups—especially columns 1, 4, 6 and rows 0, 5. Look for swaps that extend these into triples, or aim to line four identical colors to earn a striped candy. Central columns remain the most promising zone for cascade-friendly matches.

Swapping (1,0)-(1,1) turned 4-1-4-4 into 1-4-4-4, clearing a horizontal trio of 4s. The row refilled, colour totals re-balanced, and potential moves dropped from 24 to 22—proof the move was productive but didn’t open large cascades. The board now holds only two-in-a-row “almosts”, e.g. (2,3-4), (3,5-6), (4,2-3) and vertical setups in columns 2, 5 and 6. Focus next on the column-3/4 cluster: several horizontal and vertical pairs converge there, so a well-placed swap could yield another triple and possibly chain reactions that loosen the still-crowded lower rows.

The swap at (2,3) ↔ (2,4) did little: the row reverted to its original 4-2 order, no three-in-a-row formed, and overall potential matches dropped from 22 to 21. Color 1s rose while 4s fell, but the board still has only two-in-a-row “near-misses.” Good openings remain: 
• Row 3/col 5–6 (1–3) or row 4/col 5–6 (4–1) can be finished with a neighboring swap.  
• Several vertical 2-chains (e.g., col 5) are one move from completion.  
Next move should target one of these to finally clear candies and trigger cascades.
